bibl.title: Letter from Charles Whitebread to Emilie Lawrence Reed, September 10, 1926

div1.p: Whitebread requests that Emilie Lawrence Reed donate some of Walter Reed's personal effects for an exhibition at the Smithsonian Institution.

div1.head: Letter from Charles Whitebread to Emilie Lawrence Reed, September 10, 1926
div1.opener:
SMITHSONIAN INSTITUTION
UNITED STATES NATIONAL MUSEUM
WASHINGTON, D. C.
September 10, 1926.
Mrs. Walter Reed,
Blue Ridge Summit, Pa.
My dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
In 1906 the Walter Reed Memorial Association of
Baltimore, Md., loaned to the U. S. National Museum, a
marble bust of your distinguished husband. This bust is
on exhibition in a very prominent place in the Museum's
Division of Medicine, and an effort has been made by
means of photographs and biographical sketches to per-
petuate the memory of this renowned American physician,
who did so much for humanity.

Admirers of Major Reed and his work have on many
occasions expressed the wish that a collection of person-
al relics of this famous doctor might be placed on ex-
hibition near the bust, and I am taking the liberty of
addressing you on the subject with the hope that it may
be possible to obtain your cooperation in the matter.
Is there available, and would it be possible for the Mu-
seum to procure as a deposit for the purpose stated, a
uniform of Major Reed, college and society diplomas, med-
als, etc.? If you have material of this kind, but are
in doubt as to what part of it would be useful in the ar-
rangement of a Museum exhibit, I shall be glad to confer
with you on your return to the city and render such as-
sistance as I can.

In this connection, I wish to state that a very fine
collection of personal relics of the late Surgeon General
W. C. Gorgas, has just been installed in the Division of
Medicine, and Mrs. Gorgas is one of the numerous admirers
of Major Reed, who believes there should be a similar col-
lection of interesting personal effects of the man who
made possible the successful war throughout the world a-
gainst yellow fever.

Assuring you that your cooperation in this matter
will be most highly appreciated, and trusting to hear from
you on the subject, I am,
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Charles Whitebread
Charles Whitebread.
Assistant Curator,
Division of Medicine. CW/ER.
